definition[0]: to make something smaller or less in size, amount, or price
example[0]: The governor announced a new plan to reduce crime.
example[1]: The helmet law should reduce injuries in motorcycle accidents.
example[2]: Small businesses will need to reduce costs in order to survive.
example[3]: The workforce has been reduced by half.
example[4]: All the shirts were reduced to £10.
example[5]: The new bridge should reduce travelling time from 50 minutes to 15 minutes.
definition[1]: if you reduce a liquid, or if it reduces, you boil it so that there is less of it
definition[2]: to become thinner by losing weight
example[6]: He has greatly reduced the political power of the armed forces.
example[8]: They are committed to drastically reducing the size and cost of government.
example[9]: Medical progress has sharply reduced death rates.
example[10]: The aim is to gradually reduce the number of troops in the area.
heading[0]: to reduce prices, numbers, or amounts
definition[3]: to make the price, amount, or size of something less or smaller
example[12]: We need to reduce the amount of salt in our diet.
definition[4]: to reduce something, especially by a large amount – used about prices, costs, jobs, or the time needed to do something
example[13]: Companies are always looking for ways to cut costs.
example[14]: The journey time will be cut to under 2 hours.
example[15]: Staff numbers have been cut by half to about 150.
definition[5]: to reduce the level, limit, or amount of something. Lower sounds rather formal
example[16]: The voting age was lowered to 18.
example[17]: The government decided to lower interest rates by 0.5%.
example[18]: After twenty minutes, lower the temperature to 150 degrees.
definition[6]: to reduce something such as prices or costs, or reduce the level of something. Bring something down is less formal than lower
example[19]: The government wants to bring down the level of inflation.
example[20]: The company is trying to bring its costs down.
definition[7]: to reduce an amount or price by a very large amount – used especially in newspapers and advertisements
example[21]: Public spending has been slashed over the past two years.
example[22]: Prices slashed for one week only!
definition[8]: to reduce the amount of something – used especially about people deciding to spend less, do less, or use less of something
example[23]: The education budget has been cut back again.
example[24]: I need to cut back on my workload.
definition[9]: to reduce the number of people employed in order to reduce costs – used about a company or organization
example[25]: The company is planning to downsize its European operations.
definition[10]: to reduce the size or the amount of money that is being spent on something
example[26]: The research programme has been scaled down.
example[27]: The navy is being scaled down.
definition[11]: to make pain or feelings less unpleasant
example[28]: The drug is used to relieve pain.
example[29]: A joke can help to ease the tension.
definition[12]: to reduce pain or suffering, or make a problem less serious
example[30]: You can buy various medicines to alleviate the symptoms of flu.
example[31]: The new road was supposed to alleviate the congestion problem.
definition[13]: to make something less or smaller in price, amount, or size
example[32]: Jobs have been cut in order to reduce costs.
example[34]: The flight had been reduced to £99.
